Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Relationship between Maternal Social Status, Offspring Health, and Female Dispersal Success in Wild Meerkats
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many animals leave their birth places as they become adults to avoid competing or mating with relatives. However, traveling to and settling in a new area can be dangerous as animals are exposed to new diseases, predators, and unfriendly neighbors. This project is to identify the qualities that help these animals along the way, and to test whether those that are better able to withstand disease and to cope with stress are more successful. The research team will use sophisticated GPS technology to monitor the health and survival of young female Meerkats in the Kalahari Desert as they move from one social group to another. The project will also train undergraduate students and engage schoolchildren in the research through popular media and the Friends of Kalahari website. In addition to advancing our knowledge of dispersal, the results of this study will inform the ways in which we manage animals in fragmented and changing habitats.

In previous work on meerkat societies, the PIs found that dominant females, which are hormonally "masculinized", have the weakest constitutive immune responses of all group members, indicating a cost of androgen exposure in females. Moreover, because androgen concentrations vary with female social status, the PIs found evidence for organizational effects of differential prenatal androgen exposure on the health of juvenile offspring derived from dominant control (DC), subordinate control (SC), and dominant treated (DT) dams receiving an androgen-receptor blocker. Here, the PIs will follow the daughters of DC, SC, and DT dams over the next life-history stage "dispersal" to study the transgenerational effects of maternal social status/prenatal T on offspring dispersal. Using an integrated approach that combines behavioral, hormonal, and immunological analyses with novel global positioning system (GPS) telemetry data, the PIs will chart the health and social trajectories of daughters over successive stages of dispersal (during emigration from the natal group, a transience period, and settlement in a new territory). Specifically, the PIs will (1) determine dominance relationships and identify likely dispersers via regular behavioral observation; (2) fit GPS radio collars to 25 pre-dispersal females and chart their movements on an hourly basis; (3) measure immunocompetence (parasite burden and immune response) and hormone concentrations (androgens and glucocorticoids) in (a) fecal samples (collected prior to, over the course of, and following dispersal) and (b) serum samples (collected pre-dispersal and post-settlement); and (4) evaluate the health and survival of these females in their newly formed groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Animal dispersal is a key process that influences group dynamics, life-history evolution, and ultimately species survival; yet, the factors shaping individual dispersal trajectories are poorly understood. Characteristics that increase one’s probability of survival in a new environment, such as immunocompetence and the ability to respond to increased stress, should promote dispersal success. Also, dispersal has been linked to the prenatal endocrine milieu, with exposure to elevated maternal androgens predisposing offspring to leave the natal group; yet increased androgen exposure may also be immunosuppressive.

In this project, we investigated maternal effects and individual physiology across successive stages of dispersal in free-ranging, female meerkats (Suricata suricatta) at the Kalahari Meerkat Project, South Africa. The meerkat is an ideal study system, because female social status is reflected in circulating androgen concentrations; thus, offspring experience different prenatal endocrine milieus depending on whether they derive from dominant or subordinate dams. We investigated the consequences of differential prenatal androgen exposure on health and dispersal in the offspring derived from dominant control (DC), subordinate control (SC), and dominant treated (DT) dams that received an androgen-receptor blocker.

Although certain analyses remain ongoing, some of the main results are as follows: From our experimental manipulation of the prenatal hormone milieu, we found that prenatal androgen exposure is immunosuppressive. Offspring from DT dams that received an androgen receptor blocker during gestation had weaker innate immune responses and more parasites than did those from DC dams. Additionally, using structural equation models, we found that reduced prenatal androgen exposure, via effects on immune function, improves offspring survival to adulthood. Consequently for female-dominant mammals, there may be a conflict between the endocrine environment that is optimal for maximizing the mother’s competitiveness and reproductive success (high androgens) versus the environment that best contributes to the immunocompetence of her developing offspring (low androgens). That raised androgens during pregnancy can have concurrent immunosuppressive effects for dams (Smyth et al. 2016; Smyth et al. 2018) and delayed immunosuppressive effects for offspring (Smyth et al. in prep) may represent a transgenerational consequence of sexual selection operating in females.

For our study of female dispersal, we combined behavioral, hormonal, and immunological analyses with novel GPS telemetry data to chart the health and social trajectories of meerkats that left their natal groups. We found that female meerkats are immunocompromised during dispersal. Upon settlement in new groups, females that remain subordinate experience an improvement in their immune responses, whereas those that become dominant do not. Although analyses are ongoing, it is possible that offspring from subordinate dams, due to their superior immune responses compared to offspring from dominant dams, may be better equipped to successfully disperse and ultimately achieve reproductive success in new groups.

The project’s broader impacts derived from providing training opportunities for junior researchers from underrepresented groups, fostering international partnerships, and communicating findings to scientists and the public. Beyond enhancing Dr. Smyth’s graduate research, this project provided numerous professional development opportunities to Dr. Smyth by funding her travel to conferences and workshops. The interdisciplinary and international nature of this research has also enabled Dr. Smyth to deepen her existing collaborations with researchers working on the meerkat system at the Kalahari Meerkat Project, the University of Cambridge, and Zürich University. Additionally, this project has provided training and/or professional development opportunities for a high school science teacher, an undergraduate honors student at Duke University, and two post-baccalaureate research assistants. Because Dr. Smyth trained and oversaw team members, this project also provided her the opportunity to develop as a teacher and a mentor. To increase education, disseminate information, and improve public scientific awareness, we involved high-school faculty in field work, presented at numerous national and international conferences, published in peer-reviewed journals, and contributed new information to documentaries and websites aimed for the general public.
